title: STAT-462 Lab Book
text:
Welcome!
This is your home for all your instructions, labs, tutorials and projects.
You can find the class syllabus here: https://psu.instructure.com/courses/2243429/assignments/syllabus
Look at the tabs to find:

Tutorials (constantly updated)
Your Lab Overview & Labs

Project Space

This book is made using R-Markdown and Quarto Websites. If you want to learn more, visit https://quarto.org/docs/websites.

title: Lab 1: R intro
text:
The aim of this lab is to get comfortable in R and in R-Markdown, and to practice identifying some study jargon as we practiced in class. Lab instructions will be here and how-tos will be condensed into the Tutorial
The Canvas page for this lab is: https://psu.instructure.com/courses/2243429/assignments/14748231




First, please review the lab Q&A: CLICK HERE. It explains

What you need to submit
How you are graded and where the rubric is
The late policy
What counts as cheating




Review this tutorial to see some of the powerful things we can do in R.



It is very important that you are using the most recent version of R and R Studio.

title: Tutorial 1: R Basics
text: This tutorial covers accessing and using R / R Studio.

title: Tutorial index
text:
Your tutorials
Welcome to your tutorials. I have written all of these and will try and keep them up-to-date and not too overwhelming.
Know there is a search bar!
If you don’t find what you need here, see if you can find it on google or one of these useful sites:

Wonderful graphics with example code: https://r-graph-gallery.com/
Tidyverse tutorials & cheat sheets: https://www.tidyverse.org/learn/
Quatro tutorials & cheat sheets: https://quarto.org/

title: Lab Q&A
text:
You will be creating two files; an Rmd file containing your code and a .html file for viewing your finished document.
You need to submit both of these files on the relevant Canvas assignment page. Remember you can also add comments to your submission as/if needed.




There are 70 points available. Remember you can drop your lowest lab (e.g. you can skip one)
You can see the SPECIFIC RUBRIC we use for this lab on the canvas page. It’s literally how we will award the marks.
We will also provide as much feedback as possible, so please remember to click the rubric button to take a look.




Overall, here is what your lab should correspond to:




 
  
    POINTS 
    Approx grade 
    What it means 
  
 

  
    68-70 
    A* 
    Exceptional.  Above and beyond.   THIS IS HARD TO GET. 
  
  
    65-68 
    A 
    Everything asked for with high quality.   Class example 
  
  
    60-65 
    B+/A- 
    Solid work but the odd  mistake or missing answer in either the code or interpretation 
  
  
    55-60 
    B-/B 
    Starting to miss entire/questions sections, or multiple larger mistakes. Still a solid attempt.  
  
  
    49-55 
    C/C+ 
    It’s clear you tried and learned something.  Just attending labs will get you this much as we can help you get to this stage 
  
  
    40-49 
    D 
    You submit a single word AND have reached out to Dr G or Aish for help before the deadline (make sure to comment you did this so we can check) 
  
  
    30-40 
    F 
    You submit a single word…....  ANYTHING..                Think, that's 30-40 marks towards your total…. 
  
  
    0+ 
    F 
    Didn’t submit, or incredibly limited attempt.  
  









If you have technical problems & have sent me canvas message with our code and a screenshot of the issue BEFORE THE DEADLINE, all late penalties go away until we have fixed it.
Submitting late is a risk. The lab might be graded at any time past the deadline with no notice given. If worked answers are released then that is too late.
But.. I would prefer you submit late than not at all. If you’re going to be late for any reason (you don’t need to explain why), send Dr G a canvas message.
I will only start penalizing if you’re consistently late and I have sent a written warning. See the course syllabus for more info. https://psu.instructure.com/courses/2243429/assignments/syllabus




You can talk with each other to help during these labs e.g. you can see each others screens and work out answers together. I will try as much as possible to provide alternate datasets.
BUT NEVER SHARE CODE/SEND SCRIPTS.
ALL TEXT SHOULD BE IN YOUR OWN WORDS.
For example:

Working out together the right way to apply the seq() function, then each independently adding it to your own scripts is OK.
Copy/pasting your friend’s code/text is not..
So DISCUSS with friends, but then turn away to your own screen and write your own code and text.

I will be randomly running lab reports through plagiarism software.
